# Banking system stable.

Despite increased global economic and financial market uncertainties, the banking system in Hong Kong remained resilient in 2018. The effectiveness of liquidity and credit risk management systems at authorized institutions continued to be a key regulatory focus for the HKMA throughout the year. Given the continuing rise in cyber threats and the banking sector’s wider adoption of financial technology, the HKMA strengthened its supervision of authorized institutions’ technology risk management and business operations recovery capabilities. The HKMA also issued a revised Guideline on Authorization of Virtual Banks in May and began processing applications for virtual bank authorization. In conduct regulation, the HKMA took further steps to enhance the supervision of authorized institutions’ sales practices for investment and insurance products, promote accessible banking services for people with disabilities, and foster a customer-centric corporate culture.

As financial crimes become increasingly complex and globalized, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to enhance Hong Kong's capacity to combat money laundering and terrorist financing through the adoption of new technologies and a risk-based approach. The HKMA has made satisfactory progress in implementing international regulatory standards in Hong Kong, including capital adequacy standards, disclosure standards, liquidity standards, and limits on large risk exposures. Additionally, the HKMA has strengthened communication with the banking sector to ensure an appropriate balance between regulatory effectiveness and market development.

At the same time, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to ensure that Hong Kong has a credible resolution mechanism for authorized institutions, including introducing rules on minimum loss-absorbing capacity to address a major obstacle to its feasibility.

# Objective

One of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's overall objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this goal depends on establishing and maintaining a financial system with a high level of resilience and capable of providing the essential financial services needed by the Hong Kong economy.

Banks can affect the stability of the banking system through their operational practices, or even through disorderly failure in extreme circumstances. As the regulator, the Financial Secretary plays a vital role in safeguarding financial stability by ensuring banks are able to withstand shocks, respond to crises, and recover from them, ultimately helping to prevent failures. The Financial Secretary is responsible for the prudential supervision of banks, as well as the authorization of licensed banks, restricted license banks and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively referred to as “authorized institutions”). The Financial Secretary is also responsible for the designation and regulation of certain financial market infrastructure.

However, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) cannot guarantee a risk-free financial system, and Hong Kong’s prudential regulatory regime is not designed to ensure “zero risk.” As a resolution authority, the HKMA strives to ensure that if a licensed financial institution becomes unsustainable, its failure can be managed in an orderly fashion. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution framework, under which the HKMA serves as the resolution authority for certain financial institutions, including licensed institutions. To establish a smoothly functioning resolution framework in Hong Kong, it is essential to develop resolution legislation and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to address challenges to resolvability, and build the HKMA’s operational capabilities to resolve failing institutions. To effectively carry out these tasks, the HKMA needs to adopt approaches consistent with and coordinated with international standards.

# 2018: Year in Review

# Regulatory Oversight Overview

In 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) conducted a total of 187 off-site reviews, covering a wide range of areas including the CAMEL ratings of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations and risk management, as well as the business strategies of authorized institutions in response to the development of financial technology. To continue enhancing the risk governance standards of authorized institutions, the HKMA held 27 meetings with the boards of directors or their committees of authorized institutions, and monitored the progress of authorized institutions in implementing corporate governance guidelines. In addition, the HKMA held 28 trilateral meetings involving authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site reviews, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to conduct regular on-site inspections, complemented by thematic assessments to evaluate areas considered higher risk. During the year, the HKMA carried out a total of 392 on-site inspections and thematic assessments, with a primary focus on credit risk management. Other key areas of emphasis included technology risk and operational risk management, as well as measures to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA also increased the number of on-site inspections and thematic assessments relating to liquidity and market risk management, and the implementation of the Basel capital adequacy framework. Dedicated review teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions’ businesses involving securities, investment products, insurance, and mandatory provident fund (MPF) matters.

Table 1 provides an overview of the Financial Supervisory Commission's regulatory work in 2018.

# Credit Risk Supervision

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

In 2018, credit growth decelerated to 4.4%, a significant drop from the 16.1% increase seen in 2017 (Table 2). Trade financing decreased by 7.6% that year. This slowdown was primarily driven by increasing uncertainty in the global economic and trade environment, resulting in reduced credit demand.

Table 2: Growth of Loans and Advances

Mainland-related loan balances increased by 1.4% to HK$424.9 billion at the end of 2018, lower than the growth rate in 2017 (Table 3).

Table 3 Growth in Domestic-related Loans

The asset quality of accredited institutions remained stable in 2018. The specific classified loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.56% at the end of 2017 to 0.50% at the end of 2018, far below the long-term average of 2.1% since 2000; during the same period, the specific classified loan ratio for the overall banking sector decreased from 0.68% to 0.55%. Regarding mainland-related loans, the specific classified loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.75% to 0.63% in 2018, while the relevant ratio for the overall banking sector also decreased from 0.67% a year earlier to 0.54%.

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) strengthened its supervision to ensure that authorized institutions continue to adopt prudent credit risk management practices. In particular, the HKMA has taken a more proactive approach to understanding the background and structure of large corporations, thereby enhancing the monitoring system for corporate credit risk. Furthermore, the HKMA conducted targeted assessments focusing on key credit risk management monitoring measures, such as the approval criteria and risk management for large corporate loans, loan classification and provisioning systems, credit risk governance frameworks, risk management of loans to property developers, as well as mortgage loans and insurance policy-backed loans.

# Property mortgage loan

Residential property prices reached a historical high in July 2018 but showed signs of easing in the second half of the year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) eight rounds of countercyclical macroprudential measures, introduced since October 2009, have strengthened the resilience of Hong Kong's banking system against potential reversals in the local property market. The average loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgages fell from 64% in September 2009, before the HKMA introduced its first round of countercyclical measures, to 46% in December 2018. The average debt service-to-income ratio also decreased from 41% in August 2010, when the HKMA first introduced a cap on this ratio, to 34% in December 2018 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Average Loan-to-Value Ratio and Mortgage Payment-to-Income Ratio for New Residential Mortgage Loans

# Supervision of Business Operations and Technological Risks

The technology risks facing the banking sector remain relatively high. In 2016, the Financial Supervisory Commission launched the "Cyber Defense Assessment Framework." The first phase of implementation covered 30 licensed institutions, including all large banks, which have completed three stages of assessment: self-assessment of risk levels, assessment of maturity, and (where applicable) risk-informed cyber defense simulation exercises. These assessments help licensed institutions identify areas for improvement and take remedial actions to strengthen their cyber defenses. Concurrently, the Financial Supervisory Commission has established timelines for the second and third phases of implementation, which will cover the remaining licensed institutions. Within the year, the Commission will conduct on-site inspections, focusing on licensed institutions' cybersecurity controls, outsourcing arrangements, and IT governance.

# Wisdom Bank

The HKMA continues to collaborate with the banking industry on the seven measures introduced in September 2017 to promote smart banking, aiming to foster the development of fintech in Hong Kong. On the regulatory front, the HKMA issued revised guidelines on the recognition of virtual banks in May. Additionally, under the "Banking Easy" initiative, the HKMA has simplified regulatory requirements related to remote account opening, online loans, and online wealth management. These optimized regulatory requirements help banks provide better online banking user experiences. In September, the scope of the "Banking Easy" initiative was expanded to promote the adoption of financial compliance technology (Regtech) by banks. The three new focuses include monitoring technology for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, Regtech for prudential risk management and compliance, and machine-readable regulatory requirements.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Deputy Chief Executive Ruan Guohang delivered a speech at the Hong Kong Institute of Bankers’ “Hong Kong Bankers’ Summit 2018” titled “Financial Compliance Technology in the New Era of Smart Banking.”

# Regulatory Oversight of Liquidity and Market Risk

As the United States monetary policy continues to normalize, the Financial Supervisory Commission has strengthened the regulation of liquidity risk to ensure that supervised entities prudently and effectively manage their liquidity risks. This year, the Commission conducted a special assessment to evaluate the preparations supervised entities have made for potential tightening of U.S. dollar liquidity and their ability to conduct internal liquidity stress tests. In addition, the Commission is monitoring the compliance of supervised entities with the “Net Stable Funding Ratio” requirements, which took effect in January.

In addition to reviewing the market risk management of debt portfolios of authorized institutions, the Financial Supervisory Agency also conducted on-site reviews focusing on margin and risk mitigation standards for over-the-counter derivatives not cleared through central counterparties, in accordance with the Global Foreign Exchange Principles, to assess the authorized institutions’ compliance with new international standards in their financial operations.

# Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism

The Risk Assessment Report on Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing in Hong Kong, published in April, points out that Hong Kong's banking system faces high money laundering threats, similar to other international financial centers, reflecting the increasing globalization and complexity of financial services. The money laundering threats facing Hong Kong not only originate from local criminal activities but, to a greater extent, from overseas activities. These overseas activities include illegal proceeds from corruption abroad, fraudulent activities by transnational criminal organizations, tax evasion, and risks related to sanctions due to Hong Kong's status as a payment and trade hub. With the assistance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the government has formulated a Policy Statement on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, which outlines responses to these threats. The objective is to enhance the capacity to combat money laundering and terrorist financing while also attracting and facilitating legitimate businesses.

The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Financial Institutions) (Amendment) Ordinance 2018 came into effect on March 1, introducing amendments that provide flexibility in verifying customer identities to accommodate the development of technology-enabled customer onboarding by authorized institutions. The new legislation also broadens the scope of application, requiring lawyers, accountants, real estate agents, and trust or company service providers to take responsibility for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, thereby comprehensively strengthening the anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regime. These amendments, together with the amendments to the Companies Ordinance aimed at enhancing transparency of beneficial ownership of companies, will assist authorized institutions in carrying out their work against money laundering and terrorist financing.

To consolidate and further strengthen communication with licensed institutions regarding policies and regulatory approaches to combating money laundering and terrorist financing, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) issued in October a new unit under its “Regulatory Policy Manual” titled “Regulatory Approaches to Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing,” along with revised “Guidance on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing (Applicable to Licensed Institutions)” to more effectively implement a risk-based approach and reduce challenges for licensed institutions in adopting new technologies.

Information sharing plays an increasingly important role in combating money laundering and terrorist financing. With the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB), the banking sector has actively participated in the Intelligence Working Group, a collaborative effort to share information and combat financial crime, and has achieved tangible results. A review of the Working Group’s pilot scheme began at the end of 2018 and will be completed in early 2019.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

Consolidating Hong Kong's status as an international financial center is one of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's main responsibilities. Seven measures aimed at promoting the banking and payment sectors to develop and apply financial technology have made significant progress this year, with the successful launch of the fast payment system "TransferFast" serving as a prime example.

The initiative for enhanced connectivity between China's mainland and Hong Kong capital markets, along with the development of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, has further strengthened Hong Kong's unique position as a gateway to China's mainland. Hong Kong's status as an offshore RMB business hub has also become more solidified, with vibrant RMB financial activities in the city.

At the same time, the HKMA is committed to exploring new opportunities and further enhancing the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform, including infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centers, and the green bond market. The HKMA is also strengthening its marketing efforts to promote Hong Kong’s advantages to stakeholders both overseas and on the Mainland. On the international front, the HKMA plays a leading role in various regional and international committees, clearly demonstrating Hong Kong’s expertise and commitment in related international work.

# Overview

To strengthen Hong Kong's position as Asia's fintech hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to implementing seven measures announced in September 2017, aimed at promoting the development and application of fintech in the banking and payment sectors. Key progress made in advancing these seven initiatives to promote smart banking this year includes:

- Successfully launched the Fast Payment System "Faster Payment," connecting all banks and stored-value payment tools (collectively known as "e-wallets").
- Released an Open Application Programming Interface (Open API) framework for the banking industry and promoted its implementation.
- Enhanced financial technology research and talent training.
- Strengthened cross-border fintech cooperation.
- Revised the guidelines for "Virtual Bank Licensing" and processed virtual banking license applications.
- The upgraded "Fintech Regulatory Sandbox" (FSS 2.0) is operating smoothly.
- Expanded "Bank Easy" to encourage banks to adopt financial compliance technology.

The Office for Fintech Promotion under the HKMA (FFO) plays an important role in promoting and implementing the aforementioned measures in collaboration with the HKMA's various banking departments.

With the implementation of optimized measures under the China Mainland-Hong Kong capital market connectivity program, Hong Kong's unique position as the main gateway to the China Mainland has been further strengthened. The full implementation of the real-time gross settlement (DvP) model under the "Bond Connect" initiative, along with the State Council's announcement of tax exemption arrangements for overseas investors in the China's domestic bond market, has further enhanced the efficiency and appeal of the program. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has also closely cooperated with mainland authorities to explore and implement various financial support measures, facilitating individuals and businesses living, working, and operating in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA). Hong Kong's offshore RMB business continues to thrive, with the annual RMB deposit pool increasing by 6% to RMB 657.7 billion. The average daily transaction value of the RMB real-time gross settlement (RTGS) system reached a high level of RMB 10,101 billion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is actively exploring new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform. To promote the development of Hong Kong’s bond market, the HKMA has implemented the “Bond Grant Pilot Scheme” proposed in the Budget, providing subsidies to institutions issuing bonds in Hong Kong for the first time. It is also working closely with the government to amend legislation and expand the scope of tax-exempt bond investment income under the “Qualified Debt Securities Scheme.” The HKMA has also intensified its market promotion activities, promoting Hong Kong’s advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders, including hosting numerous large-scale and thematic outreach events to promote Hong Kong as a hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate finance.

At the international level, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) chairs several regional and international committees. The HKMA currently serves as Chair of the Standing Committee on Regulatory Cooperation under the Financial Stability Board, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s Task Force on Regulatory and Implementation Standards, and the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks Meeting (EMEAP).

The safe and effective operation of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure lays a solid foundation for its status as an international financial center. The four Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) systems handling interbank transactions, the Central Money Markets Unit (CMU) system, and the Hong Kong Securities Clearing and Settlement System (Hong Kong Securities Depository) all achieved 100% system availability in 2018, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Through accounts maintained with two central securities depositories on the Mainland, the CMU system continues to facilitate the settlement of northbound trading under the Bond Connect scheme, as well as holding Mainland debt securities on behalf of relevant CMU system members.

To enhance the overall security and efficiency of the retail payment industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) designated two additional retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (Payment Ordinance), bringing the number of designated retail payment systems under HKMA supervision to six. The HKMA also regulates 16 licensed stored value facility operators, who are actively introducing new products and services to provide customers with more choices and a better user experience. Meanwhile, the coverage of electronic cheques and electronic bill and payment services has further expanded to include cross-border payment transactions between Hong Kong and the entire province of Guangdong.

# 2018: A Year in Review

# Hong Kong as a Fintech Hub in Asia

# Measures to Promote Smart Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced seven measures to promote smart banking in September 2017, aiming to help the banking industry elevate to a higher level and seize the vast opportunities brought by the convergence of banking and technology. During the year, the HKMA made good progress in implementing these measures and advancing the transformation of Hong Kong's financial ecosystem.

# Fast Turnover

Fast Payment Service was successfully launched in September, enabling bank and prepaid payment tool users to make instant bank-to-bank transfers of Hong Kong dollars and Renminbi anytime, anywhere, simply by entering the recipient’s mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 prepaid payment tool operators have joined the system, providing customers with instant payment services and/or account linking services.

QuickPass has received over 2 million registrations within 3.5 months, representing 27% of Hong Kong's population. Since its launch, the system has processed over 4.8 million transactions, totaling HKD 104.9 billion and RMB 2.75 billion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the Hong Kong Retail Payment Shared QR Code Standard and its associated mobile application, "HKQR," in the same month. This globally pioneering mobile application integrates multiple QR codes into a single, unified QR code, facilitating merchants—particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs)—to accept payment solutions from different payment service providers using a single QR code, eliminating the need to display multiple QR codes to customers.

# Open Application Interface

Open APIs enable banks to share their data with third-party service providers, fostering seamless integration of banking services with other industries. This allows users to access a comprehensive range of services through a single, secure system. To encourage the development and adoption of Open APIs within the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Open API Framework in July. The framework employs a risk-based approach and is being implemented in four phases. As of January 31, 2019, 20 banks had opened approximately 500 API interfaces in the first phase, providing data access to over 1,000 products and services.

# Scientific Research and Talent Development

TradeLink, a trade finance platform built on distributed ledger technology (DLT), was launched in October by a consortium of Hong Kong banks, following a proof of concept led by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA). The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks by digitizing trade documents and automating trade finance processes. As of the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined the consortium. In October, TradeLink signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the European trade finance platform we.trade to conduct a pilot program for connecting the two platforms. The HKMA is also exploring opportunities to connect TradeLink with other regions, including collaborating with the Monetary Authority of Singapore to launch the Global Trade Connectivity Network.

Mr. Chen Der-lin, Chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (left), at the launch ceremony of "Trade Synergy."

To cultivate more fintech professionals, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the upgraded "Fintech Talent Development Program" (FCAS 2.0) in January in collaboration with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI). FCAS 2.0 consists of four programs suitable for young talents at different career development stages. Over 200 students have benefited from the program.

Mr. Chen De-lin, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the left), Dr. Lam Ka-lei, Chairman of Cyberport (first from the left), Mr. Wang Ming-hin, Chairman of the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) (second from the right), and Mr. Wong Hark-keung, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation (first from the right), attended the FCAS 2.0 launch ceremony.  
Mr. Chen De-lin, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the left), Dr. Lam Ka-lei, Chairman of Cyberport (first from the left), Mr. Wang Ming-hin, Chairman of the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) (second from the right), and Mr. Wong Hark-keung, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation (first from the right), attended the FCAS 2.0 launch ceremony.

# Cross-border Collaboration

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has continued to strengthen its financial technology collaboration with Shenzhen, following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Shenzhen Municipal Government’s Financial Services Office in 2017. This includes sponsoring the “Shenzhen FinTech Summer Internship Program,” which provides 50 students with six-week internships at leading companies in Shenzhen, immersing them in the local fintech environment. The HKMA also co-organized the “Shenzhen-Hong Kong FinTech Innovation Awards” for a second time with the Shenzhen Financial Services Office.

Mr. Li Dazhi, Deputy Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the right), speaks with the first batch of Shenzhen Fintech summer interns.

The HKMA also signed fintech cooperation agreements with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, the Polish Financial Supervision Authority, the Financial Services Regulatory Authority of the Abu Dhabi Global Market, and the Central Bank of Brazil in 2018 to promote fintech cooperation.

In August, the Financial Services and Markets Authority, along with 11 other financial regulatory bodies and related organizations, announced the "Global Financial Innovation Network" initiative. The network aims to provide innovative companies with a more effective way to engage with regulators and to foster collaboration among regulators on innovation-related issues.

# Virtual banking

The introduction of virtual banks will inject new impetus into Hong Kong’s fintech applications and provide digital banking customers with a novel experience. By targeting retail customers such as individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises, virtual banks will also help advance financial inclusion. Following a public consultation, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued the revised "Guidelines on the Recognition of Virtual Banks" in May and received approximately 30 applications by the end of August.

# FinTech Regulatory Sandbox

Sandbox usage has steadily increased throughout the year. To help build a fintech compliance ecosystem, the sandbox has been open to fintech projects since September.

As of the end of 2018, a total of 42 financial technology or technology products had been approved for testing in the regulatory sandbox, of which 28 had completed trials and their products had subsequently been released to the market. The HKMA also received 220 inquiries through the “Fintech Regulatory Chatroom,” seeking regulatory feedback during the early stages of fintech project development. Approximately 70% of these inquiries came from technology companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Inventory Management

2018 was a challenging year for investors, with the investment environment beset by numerous risk factors, including the continued normalization of US interest rates leading to tighter financial conditions, escalating trade tensions between major economies, and the rise of populism and increased geopolitical risks in various parts of the world. Global stock markets generally declined, and US Treasury yields also rose as the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates four times. Amid rising US interest rates, the US dollar strengthened. Some emerging markets faced severe domestic political and economic pressures, causing their currencies to depreciate significantly. Despite the challenging investment environment, the foreign exchange fund still recorded investment income of HKD 10.9 billion in 2018.

# Foreign Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, directly or indirectly. It may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of the monetary and financial system in Hong Kong, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the operation and investment management of the Exchange Fund, in accordance with the powers delegated to it and the provisions for further delegation by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of Foreign Exchange Reserves

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee formulates the following investment objectives for the Foreign Exchange Fund:

(a) Ensuring capital preservation;  
(b) Ensuring that the entire monetary base is always fully supported by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;  
(c) Ensuring sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and  
(d) Striving to maximize investment returns, in accordance with the above (a) to (c), in order to safeguard the fund's long-term purchasing power.

The aforementioned objectives comprehensively take into account the statutory purposes of the foreign exchange fund and have been reflected in the fund's portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

Foreign exchange funds are broadly divided into two main portfolios: support portfolio and investment portfolio. The support portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing ample backing for the currency base as stipulated by the monetary authority system. The investment portfolio primarily invests in debt and equity markets of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to safeguard asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Monetary Authority has prudently and incrementally diversified a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets into a wider range of asset classes, including emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities are held through investment portfolios, while private equity and real estate investments are held through a long-term growth portfolio. The market capitalization limit of the long-term growth portfolio is one-third of the Exchange Fund’s accumulated surpluses and the sum of future fund and Exchange Fund affiliated company deposits linked to the long-term growth portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the government for strategic purposes through the Exchange Fund. Due to its unique nature, the portfolio’s investment performance is not included in the Exchange Fund’s assessment.

# Deposits in the Foreign Exchange Fund

The Foreign Exchange Fund regularly accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for the Future Fund. Interest rates on deposits in the Future Fund are linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual interest rate depending on the proportion of the portfolios. As of the end of 2018, the Future Fund's proportion in the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was approximately 50:50.

# Investment Procedure

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on both strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation, which reflects the allocation indicated by the benchmark, shows the long-term asset allocation the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. Guided by the strategic allocation, the Exchange Fund tactically allocates assets to seek returns exceeding the benchmark. Consequently, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocations is termed “tactical deviation.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, establishes the investment benchmark and tracking error limits, and the Monetary Authority is authorized to decide on the tactical asset allocation and set the permissible range for tactical deviation. Portfolio managers can hold positions within the permissible range of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market movements.

# Investment Management

# Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)

The Financial Supervisory Commission established a Foreign Exchange Fund Investment Office in August, dedicated to investment and related risk management functions. The office’s staff are responsible for directly managing approximately 72% of the foreign exchange fund’s investments, including the entire supporting portfolio and a portion of the investment portfolio. This portion of the investment portfolio invests in global fixed income markets and executes the foreign exchange fund’s macroeconomic risk management strategies through derivative instruments.

# Outsourced Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through its internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also employs external investment managers to oversee approximately 28% of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of engaging external investment managers is to leverage the best professional investment techniques available in the market to achieve sustainable returns for the Foreign Exchange Fund, enabling it to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as to gain insights into market practices and professional investment expertise.

The expenses related to hiring external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction fees, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses are primarily influenced by market factors and vary from year to year.

# Risk Management and Supervision

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, the importance of risk management is highlighted. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for both internal and externally hired investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The Authority has also strengthened risk assessment to align with the growing diversification of the Foreign Exchange Fund's investments; it also employs risk control tools to evaluate market risks under normal and extremely adverse market conditions. Additionally, the Authority conducts detailed analysis of investment performance factors to identify the causes behind different performance outcomes, thereby assessing how to fully leverage the investment management expertise of both internal and external investment managers.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the Principles of Responsible Ownership published by the Securities and Futures Commission. These principles aim to help investors determine the best way to fulfill their ownership responsibilities in Hong Kong-listed companies. Regarding the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has established internal guidelines on environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors, applicable to the selection, appointment and monitoring of external fund managers. External fund managers appointed to actively manage the Hong Kong equity portfolio are required to comply with the Principles of Responsible Ownership when managing these investments. Overall, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA will closely monitor the development of relevant ESG standards and assess how these standards can be further incorporated into its investment processes. Furthermore, to promote international cooperation in responsible investment, the HKMA has become a member of the non-profit organization FCLTGlobal, which aims to promote business and investment decisions with a long-term orientation.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

## The 2018 Financial Market

In 2018, several risk factors previously underestimated by the market began to materialize, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of U.S. trade policy – including protectionist measures – on global trade, and geopolitical risks. These developments triggered significant volatility in international financial markets.

The escalation of the US-China trade dispute has caused investors great concern, with emerging markets and Hong Kong stocks experiencing repeated declines since the end of January, and the Hang Seng Index falling as much as 27% from its peak in that month. Starting from the fourth quarter, major European and American stock markets also declined significantly, recording two-digit percentage drops. Overall for 2018, global stock markets generally declined, with the MSCI Global Index, which covers developed market stocks, falling by 10.4%, and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index also falling by 16.6%.

In the bond market, due to the normalization of US monetary policy, US Treasury yields generally rose throughout 2018. However, the bond market still experienced fluctuations during the year. For example, the yield on 10-year US Treasury notes rose from approximately 2.5% at the beginning of the year to a seven-year high of 3.2% in November, but softened to 2.7% by year-end as investors grew concerned about the US-China trade dispute and shifted towards risk-averse investments.

In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened this year following interest rate hikes in the United States. The US Dollar Index rose 4.4%, while major currencies such as the Euro and the Renminbi depreciated approximately 5% against the dollar. Furthermore, the currencies of some emerging markets suffered further setbacks due to domestic political and economic instability. For example, the Argentine Peso and the Turkish Lira fell by approximately 50% and 30% against the dollar, respectively. In contrast, demand for safe-haven investments drove the Japanese Yen up 2.7% against the dollar.

# 金管局員工

金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。作為公營機構，金管局不斷精簡工作流程，提高效率及成本效益。金管局致力維持精簡靈活的組織架構，並盡可能透過調配現有人手推行新措施及應付不斷增加的工作量。

金管局是提供平等就業機會的僱主，並確保員工能夠在沒有歧視的環境下工作。金管局的平等機會政策適用於聘用、薪酬與福利、表現評核、晉升、調職╱培訓機會及一般行為操守等方面。

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。金管局要求其員工維持高水平的操守及道德標準，不論何時都恪守極高的個人行為及操守規範，並以金管局的最佳利益為依歸。

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬及浮動薪酬的款項；而適用於負責投資的員工的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁及以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Stay in touch with the public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains close contact with the media to enhance its transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and work. In 2018, the Authority held a total of 96 public media events, including 21 press conferences, 11 site visits, and 64 other public events. In addition, it arranged 39 media interviews during the year and issued 462 bilingual press releases, while also handling a large volume of media inquiries daily.

To enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) key functions, the HKMA organizes press briefings and workshops for local and overseas media, covering a range of topics including the linked exchange rate system, fintech development, green finance, and infrastructure financing. In addition to enriching the content of its existing YouTube channel and LinkedIn page, the HKMA also launched an official Facebook page in July, further leveraging social media to enhance communication with the public.

# Public Inquiry / Public Queries

The public inquiry service is an effective channel for enhancing public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s key functions and operations. In 2018, it handled 9,950 inquiries, approximately half of which concerned banking regulations, consumer banking issues, and banknotes and coins—particularly coin collection schemes, banking products and services, banking guidelines and announcements, the Faster Payment System, virtual banks, and the 2018 banknote series.

# Periodicals

In addition to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the Semi-Annual Report on Monetary and Financial Stability and four issues of the Quarterly Report in 2018, and regularly updated the Monthly Financial Statistics to provide the latest and thematic information and analysis on Hong Kong's monetary affairs, banking sector, and economic matters. Furthermore, the HKMA published 13 articles in the "Insight" series, explaining various thematic issues related to the HKMA's work.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 60,000 pages of information in English, traditional Chinese, and simplified Chinese, enabling the public to access the latest updates from the HKMA. The website also hosts the "Register of Recognized Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and the "Register of Securities Business Employees of Recognized Institutions," maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of Licensed Operators of Stored Value Facilities" under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features dedicated topic pages and prominent quick links to alert the public about new HKMA initiatives, such as "Faster Payments," and important timely information, such as precautions against phone scams and the parking locations of cash collection vehicles under the coin collection program.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is promoting the adoption of open application programming interfaces (APIs) within the banking sector. Starting in July, the HKMA made its own APIs available on its website to provide public access to key information. The first 50 datasets, covering frequently accessed data such as banking system and Exchange Fund statistics, as well as press releases and cash transport schedules, were successfully launched in July. The remaining 80 datasets will be rolled out in stages by mid-2019. To further improve public access to the latest news and information, the HKMA is updating its website’s design and content to make it more user-friendly. The redesigned website is expected to launch by the end of 2019.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority leads by example in promoting the development and application of open APIs.

# Public Education Program

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Financial Centre Phase 2. It introduces the work of the HKMA and enhances the public's understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre is divided into two sections: an exhibition hall and a library, and is open to the public for visits six days a week. The exhibition hall introduces the work of the HKMA and the development of Hong Kong's monetary and banking sectors. It also provides reading materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong's currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The Currency Exhibition Area at the Information Centre introduces the design, anti-counterfeiting features, production process, and other interesting facts about Hong Kong banknotes and coins. It underwent renovation in the first quarter of 2018, incorporating various interactive elements such as educational games that blend learning with fun, enabling visitors to gain knowledge about Hong Kong currency while enjoying the experience. Additionally, the exhibition features an artistic Bauhinia tree composed of 2,018 transparent cubic blocks crafted from shredded banknotes no longer suitable for circulation. This installation complements another mosaic artwork within the area, created using Hong Kong coins. The newly renovated Currency Exhibition Area reopened on 16 August.

The Information Centre provides guided tours for visitors. During the year, it welcomed over 59,000 visitors and offered guided tours to schools and other groups more than 580 times (Figure 3). Since opening in December 2003, the Centre has welcomed a total of over 705,000 visitors. Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library holds over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains the “Register of Licensed Institutions and Local Representative Offices” and the “Register of Securities Employees of Licensed Institutions” as required by Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is part of the government structure, but employs staff under non-civil service terms to attract talent with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The HKMA is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure and, where possible, implements new initiatives and handles increasing workloads by reallocating existing staff.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is an employer committed to providing equal employment opportunities and ensuring that employees can work in an environment free from discrimination. The HKMA’s equal opportunities policy covers recruitment, compensation and benefits, performance appraisal, promotion, transfer/training opportunities, and general workplace conduct.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority recruits, trains, and maintains a professional and highly capable workforce to fulfill its policy objectives and adapt flexibly to evolving job requirements. # Compensation and Benefits Policy and Salary Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary determines the salaries and service conditions of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) staff by seeking the opinions of its governing committees through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and taking into account market salary levels and practices. The compensation package includes cash compensation and the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF), along with some basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises a fixed monthly salary (basic salary) and variable pay, distributed annually based on employee performance.

The Financial Secretary reviews the salaries of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) staff annually, seeking advice from the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, which in turn considers recommendations from the HKMA’s oversight committee. This review takes into account the oversight committee’s assessment of the HKMA’s performance over the past year, the results of financial sector compensation surveys conducted by independent human resources firms, and other relevant factors. Individual employees with outstanding performance may also receive special salary adjustments to maintain their competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority allocates funds approved for adjusting annual fixed and variable compensation based on individual employee performance. The variable compensation system applicable to employees responsible for investments is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and their compensation. Adjustments to fixed compensation and the distribution of variable compensation for assistant directors and above are approved by the Financial Secretary after considering the views of the governing committee, and these employees will recuse themselves from discussions regarding their compensation. Adjustments to fixed compensation and the distribution of variable compensation for supervisors and below are determined by the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, based on the Financial Secretary’s delegated authority, and according to the entire approved fund allocated for salary payments.

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to the notes to the financial statements 2.5, 2.6 and 40.1.

As of December 31, 2018, the Group’s financial assets carried at fair value totaled HKD 36,935.89 billion, and its financial liabilities totaled HKD 11,338.29 billion.

The fair value of the remaining 7% of these financial assets is estimated using valuation techniques based on parameters not observable in the market (Level 3 parameters). These financial assets, totaling HKD 275.63 billion, primarily consist of unlisted investment funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the reliance on estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value is a key audit matter.

The audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value include:

- Understand the valuation procedures for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including related monitoring measures;  
- Evaluate and test monitoring measures, including application-level monitoring measures for computer systems;  
- Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;  
- If market quotations are used, verify prices against independent sources;  
- If the parameters used in the valuation method are based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate and whether the related assumptions are reasonable, and verify the parameters against independent sources; and  
- If the parameters used in the valuation method are not based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate, and assess the reasonableness of the related assumptions and parameters.

# The responsibilities of an auditor in relation to the audit of financial statements.

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements as a whole do not contain any material misstatements resulting from fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the audit standards of the audit office will necessarily detect any material misstatements that may exist. A misstatement is considered material if it is caused by fraud or error and if it is reasonably expected that it, individually or in aggregate, could influence the economic decisions made by users of the financial statements.

During the audit process in accordance with the Audit Office's audit standards, I will exercise professional judgment and maintain a professional skepticism. I will also:

Identify and assess the risk that financial statements may contain material misstatements due to fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Since fraud may involve collusion, falsification, intentional omission, false statements, or overriding of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements due to fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those due to error;
Understand the internal controls relevant to the audit in order to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the group's internal controls;
Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the financial management officer are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures made are reasonable;
Determine whether the financial management officer's use of the going concern basis of accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are significant uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I believe that significant uncertainty exists, it is necessary to draw the users' attention to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements in the auditor's report. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may lead to the group's inability to continue as a going concern;
Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including the disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly present the transactions and events;
Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the group to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the group audit. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timeline of the planned audit, as well as significant audit findings, including any material deficiencies in internal controls identified during the audit.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Committee under the Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, confirming that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and I will inform them of any relationships and other matters that could reasonably be considered to affect my independence, along with any relevant safeguards where applicable.
